text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6-Mate English
From BBC Learning English
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Dan and joining me today is Neil Heineel.
Hi, everyone!
speaker: Neil

text: Huh?
Huh?
Uh, a chew!
Bless you! Are you ok?
speaker: Dan

text: I think I’m coming down with something serious.
speaker: Neil

text: It’s just a case of the sniffles.
speaker: the sniffles

text: The sniffles is an informal way of saying a cold or flu.
The sniffles is an informal way of saying a cold or flu. It comes from the sniffing sound people make when they have a runny nose.
speaker: Thesnifflesa runny nose

text: Yeah, and a runny nose is when liquid mucus keeps leaking from our nose.
Usually when we're sick.
I'm afraid you'll just have to soldier on, Neil.
To soldier on means to continue despite difficulty. I’m dying! What’s it about anyway?
speaker: To soldier on

text: Oh, dying!
What's it about anyway?
It's about man-flu, and whether it's actually real or
just something that men like to complain about.
We'll give you six words and expressions and of course, our quiz question.
All right, fire away.
In a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put?
speaker: Dan

text: from a cold or flu, where women put an average of one and a half days, what did men put?
Was it A one day, B two days or C three days?
I'm going to say three days.
The threat of mad flu is real.
Well, we'll find out later, but let's clarify.
Man-flu is the tendency that many people believe men have to complain about a minor illness,
such as a cold or flu, and act as if they were suffering from something a lot more serious.
Yes. But science cannot say whether men do actually suffer more than women, or if men just tend to complain more.
speaker: Neil

text: or if men just tend to complain more.
Let's hear from this British couple about whether they think man-flu is real or not.
Men definitely do suffer a lot more, I think, than women do when we get flu.
speaker: British Man

text: Yeah, I’m not so convinced. I feel like they just complain more.
speaker: British Woman

text: I was ill recently and I just carried on and went to work and everything. And when Chris had got sick recently he was on the sofa and couldn’t really do anything, so…
speaker: British Man

text: had got sick recently, he was on the sofa and couldn't really do anything so.
And it seems that it's not just in the UK.
And it seems that it’s not just in the UK. Listen to this BBC Journalist interviewing a woman from Europe.
speaker: Dan

text: You’re from the Netherlands. Have you ever accused your boyfriend of having man flu?
speaker: BBC Journalist

text: What have you accused him of doing?
speaker: BBC Journalist

text: Wining?
Wining is when someone complains repeatedly and often in an annoying way about something.
So there certainly seems to be something there, but nothing has been proven, right?
Well, a recent scientific study has indicated that there could be something to man-flu after all.
Dr. Kyle Sue, an assistant professor of family medicine at Memorial University of Newfoundland
in Canada has suggested that there could be a difference between men and women when it comes
to respiratory diseases. Respiratory, meaning related to breathing.
He says that there was already a lot of evidence from existing studies
suggesting man experience worse, longer-lasting symptoms. Symptoms are the feelings of illness
Symptoms are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. Listen to him explain why this is.
speaker: Symptoms

text: It seems that higher the testosterone levels lower the immune response to these types of
infections, whereas the higher the estrogen level, the stronger the immune response.
Testosterone and estrogen are hormones that exist in both men and women.
Testosterone is higher in males and estrogen is higher in females. Dr. Sue's research
suggests that the more estrogen a person has, the better able they are to fight off the infection.
That's it then. Man-flu is real. Hold your horses, Neil. There are two problems.
First of all, the Royal College of GPs in the UK says that there is no such thing as man-flu.
And secondly, even Dr. Sue admits that these results, including his own, are only suggestive
and not definitive. So basically, he's saying that there is a suggestion that man-flu exists
that the evidence so far cannot say for sure. Exactly. More studies need to be done.
But you know what we can be sure about. The answer to this week's quiz question.
I asked you in a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to
recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of one and a half days, what did men put?
A, one day, B, two days or C, three days. And I said three days. And you were right. Good.
The men said they took twice as long to recover!
speaker: Dan

text: Let's review our vocabulary, shall we? Our first was the sniffles. If you have the sniffles,
Our first was the sniffles. If you have the sniffles, you have a cold, informally speaking. What's the best cure for the sniffles Neil?
speaker: the snifflesthe sniffles

text: Stay in bed and sweat it out, my mum always said. Just make sure you have lots of tissues to
deal with your runny nose. That's when a person's nose leaks mucus usually because they're ill.
Next we had soldier on. This phrasal verb means to continue despite difficulty. When was the last time you had to soldier on, Neil?
speaker: soldier onsoldier on

text: time you had to soldier on, Neil? A few days ago when I went the whole day without eating any lunch,
then we had man-flu. That's the name given to the situation where a person, often a man,
tends to complain and exaggerate a small illness such as a cold. Do you do that, Dan?
I’m sure my wife would say I do! Next we had whining. If you whine, you complain repeatedly and often in an annoying way.
speaker: whiningwhine

text: and often in an annoying way. Like my children did last time I didn't buy them ice cream. Finally,
Like my children did last time I didn’t buy them ice-cream. And finally we had symptoms. These are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. What are the symptoms of flu, Dan?
speaker: symptoms

text: flu, Dad? A headache, aching muscles, oh, and a fever. That's the end of this six-minute English.
Don't forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages. There, you made it.
You can collapse now. Bye.
